#Tip: Organize a good working team. #grantwriting
#Tip: The target audience of the #grant should be clearly explained in terms of characteristics, size and problems faced by the group.
#Tip: The review criteria are particularly important to consider in writing the proposal. #grantwriting
#Tip: The proposal should be concise and not exceed any text restrictions. #grantwriting
#Tip: Read the Program Solicitation or Announcement guidelines carefully and consider what is requested. #grantwrititng
#Tip: Identify the program or programs that best fit what you hope to accomplish. #grantwriting
#Tip: The proposal must give appropriate attention to the existing relevant knowledge base, including awareness of current literature.
#Tip: When writing a #proposal, look for previously awarded projects or work supported in other ways that are similar. #grantwriting
#Tip: Get advice from people who have been successful in the proposal process. #grantwriting

#Tip: Generate preliminary data. #grantwriting
#Tip: Enlist collaborators and include letters that clearly spell out the collaborations in your #proposal. #grantwriting
#Tip: Look at successful proposals of colleagues in your field. #grantwriting
#Tip: Contact the donor by online and by phone to reach people who want to help you. #grantwriting
#Tip: Prepare your proposal early--well before the deadline. Do not rush! #grantwriting
#Tip: Make your first proposal your best proposal. Convey your confidence and enthusiasm for the project. #grantwriting
#Tip: Do your homework and know the literature and issues, questions and controversies in your area. #grantwriting
#Tip: Place your work in perspective. Cite others. If there are two camps, make sure you cite both sides. #grantwriting
#Tip: Make your priorities clear. Provide a timeline. #grantwriting

#Tip: Follow all directions and make sure you have included all required attachments and documentation. #grantwriting
#Tip: Emphasize very clearly how the grant will be used. #grantwriting
#Tip: Get to the point; don’t say the same things over and over. Sometimes less is more! #grantwriting
#Tip: Know how much your project/purchase costs and how much you are requesting from the specific funding source. #grantwriting
#Tip: If your need is for an on-going purpose, note in the application how it will be funded in the future. #grantwriting
#Tip: Know the needs of your organization and how they line up with our objectives. #grantwriting
#Tip: Some funders require a letter of intent, or pre-application form. #grantwriting
#Tip: Review past amounts awarded so you are in line with what the foundation is currently donating. #grantwriting
#Tip: Research the funding interest of the foundation before applying and read the guidelines. #grantwriting

#Tip: Read and make sure you are clear about the application guidelines and requirements. #grantwriting
Letters of support are often optional but can be very helpful in lending credibility to your organization’s grant application. #grantwriting
#Tip: Give yourself plenty of time so you can set your application aside and revisit it one last time before submitting it. #grantwriting
#Tip: Make sure that your goals are achievable, including the timeline and budget. #grantwriting
#Tip: Use simple, clear, well thought-out words and sentences. Be concise! #grantwriting
#Tip: A well-documented “Needs Statement” is critical to your proposal. #grantwriting
#Tip: Write so the reader, any reader, from any profession, can read and understand your proposal. #grantwriting
Never write a proposal if you have not first developed the project. Develop the initiative first; apply for funding second. #grantwriting
#Tip: Know your grantor! After reviewing the grant guidelines, speak with the program officer about your proposal. #grantwriting

#Tip: Provide explanation as to why the donor should support your project. #grantwriting
#Tip: Give yourself plenty of time so you can set your application aside and revisit it one last time before submitting. #grantwriting
#Tip: Letters of support can be very helpful in lending credibility to your organization’s grant application. #grantwriting
Is this a new program that you expect will become self-sustaining or funded in other ways in the long-term? #grantwriting
Are the services provided by your project or program duplicated by any other organization? #grantwriting
Are there other sources of funds for this project?  Have you pursued them, or are you planning to do so? #grantwriting
How many people will be affected by the project or program? #grantwriting
Will the funds be used locally for local impact? #grantwriting
#Tip: Make sure that your goals are achievable, including the timeline and budget. #grantwriting
Determine the project goals, then identify the objectives that define how you will focus the work to accomplish those goals. #grantwriting
Define the scope of work to focus your funding search. #grantwriting
What is your relationship with the community you wish to help? #grantwriting
Does your budget add up? Does the project really need everything requested? #grantwriting
How will you let the funder know if the project is successful? Do you have a proven evaluation method? #grantwriting
#Tip: Have an experienced colleague read your proposal. Better yet, have two or three of them read it. #grantwriting
#Tip: Explain the applied outcomes of the research, if there are any. #grantwriting
#Tip: Tell the reviewers immediately what you are intending to research. #grantwriting
